greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Product_{d | n} tau(d).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) = Product_{i=1..omega(n)} (b_i+1)!^(tau(n)/(b_i+1)), where omega(n) is the number of distinct prime factors of n, tau(n) is the number of divisors of n, and n = p_1^(b_1)*p_2^(b_2)* ... *p_{omega(n)}^(b_{omega(n)}). - _Anand Rao Tadipatri_, Aug 04 2020
example: For n = 6: divisors of 6: 1, 2, 3, 6; tau(d): 1, 2, 2, 4; product _{d | n} tau(d) = 1*2*2*4 = 16, where tau = A000005.
mathematica: Table[Product[DivisorSigma[0, i], {i, Divisors[n]}], {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Apr 26 2012 *)
a[1] = 1; a[n_] := Module[{e = FactorInteger[n][[;; , 2]]}, d = Times @@ (e + 1); Times @@ ((e + 1)!^(d/(e + 1)))]; Array[a, 100] (* using the Formula section,  _Amiram Eldar_, Aug 04 2020 *)
program: A211776(n) = { my(m=1); fordiv(n, d, m *= numdiv(d)); m };
A211776(n) = prod(d=1, n, if((n % d), 1, numdiv(d)));
results.author: _Jaroslav Krizek_, Apr 20 2012
